29.53.text: that people can see into the future.

59.42.text: So firstly, thinking just about precognition, as it turns out,

62.79.text: just last year a researcher called Daryl Bem conducted

65.32.text: a piece of research where he found evidence

67.15.text: of precognitive powers in undergraduate students,

70.81.text: and this was published in a peer-reviewed academic journal

73.38.text: and most of the people who read this just said, "Okay, well,

75.66.text: fair enough, but I think that's a fluke, that's a freak, because I know

77.85.text: that if I did a study where I found no evidence

80.68.text: that undergraduate students had precognitive powers,

83.19.text: it probably wouldn't get published in a journal.

86.74.text: And in fact, we know that that's true, because

89.60.text: several different groups of research scientists tried

92.13.text: to replicate the findings of this precognition study,

95.65.text: and when they submitted it to the exact same journal,

98.28.text: the journal said, "No, we're not interested in publishing

101.43.text: replication. We're not interested in your negative data."

105.96.text: So this is already evidence of how, in the academic

108.71.text: literature, we will see a biased sample of the true picture

113.58.text: of all of the scientific studies that have been conducted.

117.05.text: But it doesn't just happen in the dry academic field of psychology.

121.48.text: It also happens in, for example, cancer research.

125.85.text: So in March, 2012, just one month ago, some researchers

129.92.text: reported in the journal Nature how they had tried

132.82.text: to replicate 53 different basic science studies looking at

140.22.text: and out of those 53 studies, they were only able

145.93.text: Forty-seven out of those 53 were unreplicable.

150.27.text: And they say in their discussion that this is very likely

156.82.text: People will do lots and lots and lots of different studies,

158.92.text: and the occasions when it works they will publish,

161.04.text: and the ones where it doesn't work they won't.

162.71.text: And their first recommendation of how to fix this problem,

166.66.text: because it is a problem, because it sends us all down blind alleys,

169.94.text: their first recommendation of how to fix this problem

171.65.text: is to make it easier to publish negative results in science,

175.04.text: and to change the incentives so that scientists are

177.95.text: encouraged to post more of their negative results in public.

182.30.text: But it doesn't just happen in the very dry world

186.15.text: of preclinical basic science cancer research.

190.01.text: It also happens in the very real, flesh and blood

197.25.text: some researchers did a study on a drug called lorcainide,

200.26.text: and this was an anti-arrhythmic drug,

202.59.text: a drug that suppresses abnormal heart rhythms,

204.86.text: and the idea was, after people have had a heart attack,

207.09.text: they're quite likely to have abnormal heart rhythms,

208.62.text: so if we give them a drug that suppresses abnormal heart

211.00.text: rhythms, this will increase the chances of them surviving.

214.71.text: Early on its development, they did a very small trial,

219.37.text: Fifty patients got lorcainide, and of those patients, 10 died.

223.02.text: Another 50 patients got a dummy placebo sugar pill

226.06.text: with no active ingredient, and only one of them died.

229.02.text: So they rightly regarded this drug as a failure,

231.67.text: and its commercial development was stopped, and because

234.54.text: its commercial development was stopped, this trial was never published.

238.88.text: Unfortunately, over the course of the next five, 10 years,

244.28.text: other companies had the same idea about drugs that would

248.11.text: prevent arrhythmias in people who have had heart attacks.

250.70.text: These drugs were brought to market. They were prescribed

252.42.text: very widely because heart attacks are a very common thing,

255.83.text: and it took so long for us to find out that these drugs

259.67.text: also caused an increased rate of death

262.58.text: that before we detected that safety signal,

265.33.text: over 100,000 people died unnecessarily in America

271.38.text: from the prescription of anti-arrhythmic drugs.

278.43.text: the researchers who did that 1980 study, that early study,

281.99.text: published a mea culpa, an apology to the scientific community,

285.83.text: in which they said, "When we carried out our study in 1980,

288.96.text: we thought that the increased death rate that occurred

290.89.text: in the lorcainide group was an effect of chance."

294.25.text: The development of lorcainide was abandoned for commercial reasons,

296.28.text: and this study was never published;

297.92.text: it's now a good example of publication bias.

300.31.text: That's the technical term for the phenomenon where

302.20.text: unflattering data gets lost, gets unpublished, is left

306.44.text: missing in action, and they say the results described here

309.81.text: "might have provided an early warning of trouble ahead."

314.62.text: Now these are stories from basic science.

317.83.text: These are stories from 20, 30 years ago.

322.62.text: The academic publishing environment is very different now.

325.76.text: There are academic journals like "Trials," the open access journal,

329.76.text: which will publish any trial conducted in humans

332.41.text: regardless of whether it has a positive or a negative result.

335.72.text: But this problem of negative results that go missing in action

339.68.text: is still very prevalent. In fact it's so prevalent

343.24.text: that it cuts to the core of evidence-based medicine.

349.09.text: So this is a drug called reboxetine, and this is a drug

352.11.text: that I myself have prescribed. It's an antidepressant.

354.64.text: And I'm a very nerdy doctor, so I read all of the studies

357.18.text: that I could on this drug. I read the one study that was published

360.23.text: that showed that reboxetine was better than placebo,

363.18.text: and I read the other three studies that were published

365.04.text: that showed that reboxetine was just as good as any other antidepressant,

368.61.text: and because this patient hadn't done well on those other antidepressants,

370.80.text: I thought, well, reboxetine is just as good. It's one to try.

373.27.text: But it turned out that I was misled. In fact,

376.66.text: seven trials were conducted comparing reboxetine

379.11.text: against a dummy placebo sugar pill. One of them

381.82.text: was positive and that was published, but six of them

384.13.text: were negative and they were left unpublished.

388.18.text: Three trials were published comparing reboxetine

389.92.text: against other antidepressants in which reboxetine

392.15.text: was just as good, and they were published,

393.94.text: but three times as many patients' worth of data was collected

398.33.text: which showed that reboxetine was worse than

400.20.text: those other treatments, and those trials were not published.

408.66.text: Now you might say, well, that's an extremely unusual example,

410.79.text: and I wouldn't want to be guilty of the same kind of

415.78.text: that I'm accusing other people of.

417.57.text: But it turns out that this phenomenon of publication bias

419.45.text: has actually been very, very well studied.

421.58.text: So here is one example of how you approach it.

423.80.text: The classic model is, you get a bunch of studies where

426.24.text: you know that they've been conducted and completed,

428.42.text: and then you go and see if they've been published anywhere

430.74.text: in the academic literature. So this took all of the trials

433.61.text: that had ever been conducted on antidepressants

435.76.text: that were approved over a 15-year period by the FDA.

439.40.text: They took all of the trials which were submitted to the FDA as part of the approval package.

443.16.text: So that's not all of the trials that were ever conducted on these drugs,

446.36.text: because we can never know if we have those,

448.46.text: but it is the ones that were conducted in order to get the marketing authorization.

451.95.text: And then they went to see if these trials had been published

454.30.text: in the peer-reviewed academic literature. And this is what they found.

456.87.text: It was pretty much a 50-50 split. Half of these trials

460.04.text: were positive, half of them were negative, in reality.

463.64.text: But when they went to look for these trials in the peer-reviewed academic literature,

468.38.text: what they found was a very different picture.

470.61.text: Only three of the negative trials were published,

474.98.text: but all but one of the positive trials were published.

479.63.text: Now if we just flick back and forth between those two,

483.39.text: you can see what a staggering difference there was

485.98.text: between reality and what doctors, patients,

489.43.text: commissioners of health services, and academics

492.05.text: were able to see in the peer-reviewed academic literature.

495.33.text: We were misled, and this is a systematic flaw

503.12.text: In fact, there have been so many studies conducted on

505.78.text: publication bias now, over a hundred, that they've been

509.17.text: collected in a systematic review, published in 2010,

512.36.text: that took every single study on publication bias

516.42.text: Publication bias affects every field of medicine.

519.28.text: About half of all trials, on average, go missing in action,

523.59.text: and we know that positive findings are around twice as likely

526.65.text: to be published as negative findings.

529.70.text: This is a cancer at the core of evidence-based medicine.

533.76.text: If I flipped a coin 100 times but then

537.63.text: withheld the results from you from half of those tosses,

540.89.text: I could make it look as if I had a coin that always came up heads.

544.29.text: But that wouldn't mean that I had a two-headed coin.

546.11.text: That would mean that I was a chancer

547.83.text: and you were an idiot for letting me get away with it. (Laughter)

550.94.text: But this is exactly what we blindly tolerate

554.58.text: in the whole of evidence-based medicine.

558.37.text: And to me, this is research misconduct.

562.80.text: If I conducted one study and I withheld

565.54.text: half of the data points from that one study,

568.54.text: you would rightly accuse me, essentially, of research fraud.

573.25.text: And yet, for some reason, if somebody conducts

576.03.text: 10 studies but only publishes the five that give the result that they want,

580.59.text: we don't consider that to be research misconduct.

585.94.text: a whole network of researchers, academics,

589.10.text: industry sponsors, journal editors, for some reason

594.09.text: but the effect on patients is damning.
